awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Single-shot X-ray Phase-contrast Imaging Using Deep Learning Approaches
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project relates to the benefits of next-generation X-ray imaging systems. The proposed single-shot platform overcomes the current barriers to widespread commercialization of Differential Phase Contrast (DPC) X-ray imaging. If successful, the single-shot technology will enable the development and application of next generation X-ray imagers for detecting liquids, small explosives, and other security threats for aviation and business applications. Reducing false alarm rates at airports will increase customer satisfaction, improve security, and reduce cost. DPC imaging could also substantially increase the detection of food pests, thereby reducing food waste and saving billions of dollars. In another market, non-destructive testing could significantly improve the inspection of additive manufacturing products, reducing manufacturing time through fewer iterations and creating high-quality products. Medical DPC imagers would provide MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging)-like resolution and diagnostics at an order of magnitude lower cost than current MRI.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project aims to develop a deep-learning approach to realize “single-shot” X-ray phase-contrast imaging. To commercialize the technology, the deep-learning algorithm needs to identify more complicated real-world objects effectively and accurately. Deep-learning methods require thousands to millions of training samples to make a reliable model. However, no imaging library for this unique technology currently exists. The research and development plan initially incorporates the standard slow scanning method of X-ray phase-contrast imaging to obtain DPC tri-signature computed tomography (CT) images. The tri-signature CT images provide the basis for precise material characterization (e.g., absorption coefficients, indices of refraction, and scatter characteristics). Once the materials have been characterized, they form the basis for creating millions of numerical representations of real-world objects. These objects subsequently form the core for effectively and efficiently training deep-learning models without further experimentation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
A grating-based X-ray phase-contrast imaging system enables X-ray differential phase-contrast (DPC) and dark-field (DF) images acquired simultaneously with conventional X-ray absorption (ABS) images. DPC and DF images provide additional orthogonal measurements of X-ray-matter interaction complementary to ABS images. DPC images reveal significantly higher material contrast than ABS images because the real part of the refractive index decremental, 𝛿, in materials illuminated by X-rays, is more than two orders of magnitude larger than the imaginary part, 𝛽. As a result, DPC images provide better detailed structure in soft materials such as biological specimen, fruits and water-like media. DF images signify material discrepancies for defect detection. Despite the advantages of an X-ray phase-contrast imaging system, conventional data acquisition of DPC images is slow and requires fine scans of system components.

3Fates-Xray, Inc. has developed a deep-learning (DL) based algorithm to address this major obstacle for widespread applications through recording of only one encoded X-ray image without any scanning. The successful development of single-shot X-ray phase contrast imaging enables straightforward tri-signature X-ray imaging with a static hardware upgrade kit to a conventional X-ray imaging system. No delicate mechanical motion implementation is needed.

3Fates-Xray, Inc. used images of real-world objects with non-uniform material property distributions and complex internal textures to develop deep-learning models to perform single-shot X-ray phase contrast imaging. We tested our final model further with quantitative tri-signature CT values 𝛽, 𝛿, 𝜖 (separately reconstructed from a series of ABS, DPC, and DF projection images) from single-shot projection images for data accuracy evaluations. For the majority of the test cases, the accuracy of the single shot tri-signature values is within << 5% error compared to a golden test standard. We have also shown that our single-shot imaging is directly generalizable to imaging objects not used to build the model. 

Our team has interacted with TSA, USDA, and industrial non-destructive testing (NDT) companies for discussions of applications of our single-shot imaging technology to airport security, agricultural inspections, and industrial NDT. The need for fast imaging and better material discrimination is coherent with the capabilities of our unique technology. Application of the 3Fates-Xray, Inc. technology may improve work efficiency, reduce waste, improve public safety, and protect agricultural economics.

The outcome of the SBIR Phase I project accomplished a critical milestone for 3Fates-Xray, Inc., proving that our approach applies to real-world objects with non-uniform material property distributions and complex internal textures.

The Phase I results provide a platform for further commercialization of DPC single shot imaging.

 


Last Modified: 11/26/2024
Modified by: Yao-Te Cheng
